text: Thank you very much. My name is Chris Seaman, and I'm the resident of the Whitehall district.  Along with my spouse, I'm the parent of two children ages eight and five who are enrolled at Brownsville Elementary here in Crozet. I'm also an attorney and a law professor, though my comments tonight are solely in my personal capacity. I want to express my deep disappointment in the school board's apparent acquiescence to Senate Bill 739, the recently enacted mask optional law.  Without the benefit of a public discussion or hearing, the district announced just hours after SB 739's enactment that it would adopt a mask optional policy effective March 1st, despite serious concerns about the law's validity under both the Virginia Constitution and federal law. First, SB 739 violates Article 8 of the Virginia Constitution, which provides that local school boards are vested with exclusive power over the supervision of schools in each school district.  Under well-settled precedent, the supervisory power includes a district's decision to protect the health, safety, and welfare of its students. SB 739 violates this by unlawfully prohibiting districts from continuing universal indoor masking, which, as the district's own website states, is one of the most effective tools in stopping the spread of COVID. Second, I would argue that SB 739 is not legally effective until after the end of the school year.  Article 4, Section 13 of the Virginia Constitution requires a fourth if supermajority to enact an emergency clause and expedite the effective date of a session law like 7 SB 739 before July 1st. But both the Virginia House and Senate votes fell far short of this required supermajority. And so the current policy requiring universal indoor masking should remain enforced in my view. Third and most importantly, SB 739 contains no exceptions to protect children with disabilities  who are especially vulnerable to severe disease from COVID due to a variety of medical conditions, including asthma, diabetes, autoimmune disorders, lung conditions, and cancer. Federal law, including the Americans with Disabilities Act, requires that districts accommodate these students by providing a safe in-person educational environment, which, in the judgment of numerous federal court decisions across the country, includes universal indoor masking in classroom settings. My older son is one of these children.  He has been battling leukemia for over three years and is immunocompromised from his extensive treatments, including a bone marrow transplant. He desperately wants to return to school as soon as he can do so safely, but he simply cannot if masks are optional as it would place him at risk for severe COVID. We are lead plaintiffs with a number of other parents in a lawsuit against the state on this particular issue.  It is clearly not yet time to go mask optional. Although cases are declining statewide, we are still at the highest level of transmission here in Albemarle County, according to the Virginia Department of Health. Moreover, the board's current COVID-19 update states that there are multiple classrooms with multiple positive cases within each classroom and staff capacity is currently strained due in part to COVID. And some, I urge you to reconsider your decision to go mask optional starting next week. No parent should be forced to choose between their child's health  and their education. Thank you for your time.

text: Good evening, school board members.  My name is Maya Kumazawa, Director of Budget and Planning. It's good to see you all again at our second work session. As a recap, the purpose of our work session is to unpack the draft funding requests, answer your questions, and get feedback and guidance in preparation for developing and approving the school board's funding request. This evening is the second of three scheduled work sessions. You're scheduled to approve a school board's funding request on March 10th,  and that will be formally presented to the Board of Supervisors on March 14th. Our agenda for this evening focuses on human resources and organizational development. We have a great group of staff from this department who will present and answer any questions you have in these areas. And if needed, we'll schedule a break after the compensation increase and the healthcare fund discussion.  As a review of the work session last week and the budget overview, this pie chart represents the expense breakdown in the draft funding request. Compensation and benefits make up 86% of the proposed budget and naturally the compensation and benefits are driving a majority of the increases in the draft funding request.  With regards to our learning for all strategic plan, we will be focusing in two specific strategies under the third goal area, which staff will elaborate on later. Strategy one, ACPS will implement a total compensation structure that makes us highly competitive compared to other employers and to other employers. And strategy three, ACPS will research, develop and stand up an employee services department that functions solely  for the Albemarle County Public Schools Division. Each of our new proposals that you will see is guided by a logic model in the budget document. As we have stated previously within our budget goals, we have a goal that states, schools, departments, and strategic proposals will incorporate the use of logic models  and performance measures to assist in making decisions that support budget priorities related to the strategic plan with a goal of using metrics as a management and decision-making tool during the budget process. So we have four primary components within our logic models called inputs, activities, outputs, and outcomes. Inputs and activities ensure that we follow through and fully implement the proposals we put forward  and outputs and outcomes represent success measures. They should be measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound. For the proposals that will be presented this evening, staff will provide a summary of proposed outputs and outcomes for your review. In addition, I want to bring your attention to page A59 in the budget document.  This page features a dashboard of previous year's budget proposals since FY20. text: During phase one, first year of the substitute program improvements, we piloted a regular substitute model. In this model, we had one FTE assigned to move or float weekly  to fill daily substitute assignments between the Greer, Jewett, and AHS feeder pattern. We received feedback from the office associates and administrators that the substitute was needed each day at the assigned school to fill assignments with no opportunities during the week to support other schools. This year's proposal improves on the pilot study by utilizing an allocation for the school-based substitute  like the allocation for a teaching assistant. This allows for an increased number of school-based substitutes that can serve schools and students. One school-based substitute is equivalent to .33 FTE. The school-based substitute position has the same requirements as a regular daily position.  Furthermore, the school-based substitute position provides an opportunity for entry-level employees to gain some experience and decide if they would like to pursue teaching as a career. This is a great opportunity for our current teaching assistants who would like to begin or complete a teacher education program, and or for current and future college students who desire and need a paid position with benefits.  We see this position as a potential pipeline for future ACPS teachers. In addition, serving as a permanent school-based substitute, one can develop strong connections and relationships with students and staff and become an integral part of the school staff. The school-based substitutes would know our students, the school routines and division goals, et cetera.  There would be opportunities for collaboration with teachers, involvement in school activities, after school clubs, and community events, engagement during planning and PLC meetings, as well as participation in professional development sessions. This year's proposal also adds one FTE central level substitute coordinator.  Currently, one of our HR office associates coordinates the program along with her other duties. Having a designated central level substitute coordinator would provide focus and dedicated resources to this position. The central level substitute coordinator will maintain the employment life cycle of all ACPS substitutes, including recruiting, onboarding, managing access to frontline, the substitute management system,  customer service, performance management, as well as providing ongoing training and development to substitutes. The next slide provides information regarding the proposed school-based substitute standard. For example, each elementary school would receive one school-based substitute. text: Good evening, board members. And I'm so excited to share one more proposal with you tonight that really does take our employees into consideration. You will find this proposal on pages A, 44 and 45 in the budget book with the staffing standards on page G6. And the staffing, the proposal is around increasing our number of elementary school principals or changing the staffing standard for them. The work of school leaders is invaluable when it comes to ensuring that we have high quality teaching and learning happening in our schools.  The interactions between principal and assistant principals around instructional leadership with teachers, the relationships built with students and their families, and the overall logistics of managing a school are vital to student and staff success. The work of school leaders is similar across all of our schools, large and small, and each with their own complexities.  The current staffing standard for elementary assistant principals is one per school where the enrollment is over 350 students and two per school where the enrollment is over 700. That standard leaves our five small elementary schools without an assistant principal.  When there is one person as a sole administrator, it is challenging to meet all of the demands and expectations placed on our principals. Recognizing the importance of building relationships, of leadership, and the unique challenges placed on principals in small schools, this budget proposal shifts the staffing standard to have an assistant principal in each of our elementary schools, with an additional AP continuing at a school that is larger than 700.  The proposal would add five elementary assistant principals, one each to Broaduswood, Murray, Red Hill, Scottsville, and Stony Point. Next slide, please.  Across the school division, we have seen the demands placed on our school leaders to have increased. There are increased demands regarding testing requirements, student health requirements, safety and security, and overall logistics. Additionally, our strategic plan calls for a more direct attendance and involvement of our administrators in professional learning communities or PLC meetings.  We ask that they establish stronger relationships between the home and the school and to provide feedback and coaching around instructional practices as outlined in our learning walks in our educator performance appraisal.  Finally, if a principal is unavailable, whether for division level meetings or while in PLCs or student related meetings, or for illness or other things that may pull them away, a small school may be without administrative coverage and support. In past years, a designee has served as an acting administrator when the principal was out.  and that seemed to work well in that time period. However, in our current state, it is not unusual for a sole principal to request an administrator coverage when they are out of the building, even for just a few hours. Adding an assistant principal to those schools would add continuity with students, staff, and parents if the principal is unavailable, as the need for coverage would not exist.  While these positions may not be limited to novices, being an assistant principal in one of our small schools is a great entry-level position for an aspiring administrator. It is in a time where we see fewer educators choosing to go into administration, these roles may assist with planning for succession for us. Next slide, please.  And finally, I'll go to the logic model. The outputs that we intend to see in this, with the addition of the assistant principals in our small schools, is that the number of learning walks that are completed by the end of the first semester will show an increase over prior year data. These learning walks allow us to see trends in our classroom, focusing on the guaranteed viable curriculum, culturally responsive teaching practices, and the use of adopted resources.  Additionally, we anticipate seeing increased attendance by administrators in PLC meetings when compared to prior years. And when we check in with our principals, we anticipate hearing statements that indicate an increased level of job satisfaction. Longer term outcomes, we will include feedback from surveys that we put out around greater, where we anticipate hearing about greater job satisfaction, greater support, and greater family connection.  Again, this proposal is about changing the staffing standard to add five assistant principals, one to each of our small elementary schools.
